column14: Outdoor equipment adjacent to data hall building. Weather-dependent testing. Includes medium voltage distribution, transformers, and cooling plant equipment.

Testing Notes: MV transformer: Insulation resistance (megger), turns ratio, polarity, power factor/tan delta, winding resistance, temperature rise testing, protective relay settings verification
Larger capacity requires additional temperature rise testing time and more complex relay coordination
MV switchgear: Primary/secondary injection testing of protective relays, breaker timing, contact resistance, insulation resistance, operational sequences
Main MV distribution: Extensive relay testing, coordination verification, interlocks, SCADA integration, metering accuracy
Free-cooling chiller: Full operational testing, capacity verification, control sequences, safeties, economizer operation, staging
Flow verification, temperature stratification monitoring, level controls, isolation valves

column14: GRAY SPACE OUTDOOR SUBTOTAL: 123 pieces | Electrical: 423 hrs (L4) + 101 hrs (L5) | Mechanical: 648 hrs (L4) + 216 hrs (L5)
Indoor electrical and mechanical rooms. Includes main power distribution, UPS systems, backup batteries, and electrical room cooling.

Testing Notes: 480V main distribution: Breaker testing, protective device coordination, ground fault, arc flash verification, load balancing, metering
Higher ampacity mechanical boards: More extensive load testing and coordination verification required
Modular UPS: Full functional test including bypass operation, load transfer, battery discharge, parallel operation, alarms, monitoring
Fan wall: Airflow measurement, control sequences, VFD operation, temperature/humidity monitoring, staging algorithms
Li-ion battery strings: BMS verification, cell voltage monitoring, temperature monitoring, discharge testing (sampling), isolation verification

column14: GRAY SPACE INDOOR SUBTOTAL: 519 pieces | Electrical: 1,211 hrs (L4) + 396 hrs (L5) | Mechanical: 88 hrs (L4) + 33 hrs (L5)
Data hall white space equipment. This is the BASE configuration per RFP and proposal assumptions. Includes rack power distribution, cooling distribution, and hot aisle containment.

Testing Notes: Containment: Pressure verification, door interlocks, monitoring system integration, airflow patterns
Rack PDU: Breaker verification, metering accuracy, remote monitoring, load testing, branch circuit verification
RDP: Functional testing, breaker coordination, monitoring, feeder verification
Cooling distribution: Flow/pressure testing, temperature differential verification, control sequences, leak testing, valve operation
Data hall fan walls: Airflow measurement and balancing, control integration, VFD testing, staging sequences, temperature control

column14: WHITE SPACE SUBTOTAL: 246 pieces | Electrical: 341 hrs (L4) + 87 hrs (L5) | Mechanical: 938 hrs (L4) + 326 hrs (L5)

Testing Notes: L5 IST: Complete electrical system load testing, transfer scenarios, N+1 verification, failure mode testing
L5 IST: Integrated cooling system performance, load following, economizer modes, redundancy verification
Heat load testing with load banks: Ramp testing, steady-state operation, cooling response, power quality
Full facility monitoring integration: Alarms, trending, remote monitoring, control sequences
Emergency scenarios: EPO testing, utility failure, cooling failure, UPS transfer, generator start (if applicable)

column14: SYSTEMS INTEGRATION SUBTOTAL: L5 Only: 500 hours | Electrical: 40 hrs | Mechanical: 120 hrs | Both: 340 hrs

Testing Notes: Electrical systems: transformers, switchgear, UPS, batteries, rack power
Electrical system integration and testing
Total electrical commissioning hours (35% of total)
Mechanical systems: chillers, CDUs, CRAH units, buffer tanks, containment
Mechanical system integration and testing
Total mechanical commissioning hours (31% of total)
No integration activities in L4
Load testing, DCIM, emergency scenarios requiring both disciplines
Cross-discipline integration activities (5% of total)

L5 Hours Per Unit: Equipment-level functional testing, heat load testing, system level testing
Integrated systems testing with full facility coordination
Test procedure development not included per assumption; this is execution coordination
Weekly coordination meetings and daily reporting
15% contingency for equipment deficiencies requiring retest
Total commissioning hours for single 36 MW block (rounding adjustment: 7,342 hours)
Level 4 Functional Performance Testing, Heat Load Testing, System Level Testing
Total direct commissioning execution hours (L4 + L5 only, before overhead)
Total hours including documentation coordination (11%), project management (5%), and contingency (14%)

Commissioning Level: Electrical systems expertise: transformers, switchgear, UPS, power distribution. Direct oversight and execution of L4/L5 electrical testing
Mechanical systems expertise: chillers, CDUs, CRAH units, cooling systems. Direct oversight and execution of L4/L5 mechanical testing
Hands-on electrical testing, data collection, equipment setup, test execution
Hands-on mechanical testing, equipment setup, test execution, data collection
Backup for schedule flexibility, cross-discipline support, peak demand periods
Backup technician for peak demand periods, equipment deficiency support
Program oversight, vendor coordination, client communication, schedule management, issue resolution. Oversees and directs all L4/L5 commissioning activities across all blocks
Documentation QA/QC, report generation, data management, scheduling support, test procedure formatting, submittal tracking

L5 Hours Per Unit: Cx Manager: 50 hrs/week × 6 weeks = 300 hrs | Doc Coordinator: 25 hrs/week × 6 weeks = 150 hrs
Total available hours per 6-week block: 3,450 hours (includes management and documentation support)

Description: FEASIBLE - 6.1 weeks with 10-person site crew + management support
FEASIBLE - Can complete in 3 weeks with current site resources
REQUIRES 10.3 weeks with 10-person site crew; 7-8 weeks more realistic target
Cx Manager and Doc Coordinator provide program oversight across all blocks; not direct execution hours

Voltage/Rating: TIGHT but achievable with Cx Manager oversight and Doc Coordinator support
AGGRESSIVE - can be compressed to 1 week if L4 goes smoothly; 2 weeks safer
FEASIBLE with strong Cx Manager coordination and efficient execution
RECOMMENDED - Provides margin for deficiencies and weather delays

Discipline: MEDIUM - Achievable with good GC readiness and strong management
LOW - Provides schedule margin for blocks with issues
VERY LOW - Comfortable schedule with full contingency

Equipment Type: Cx Manager (hybrid/remote) provides continuous oversight across ALL six 36 MW blocks simultaneously during overlapping phases (Oct-Dec 2026). Role is program-level, not dedicated to single block.
Documentation Coordinator (50% hybrid/remote) supports all active blocks with centralized documentation QA/QC, reporting, and scheduling coordination.
Peak period (Oct-Dec): Blocks 3, 4, 5 overlap. Cx Manager and Doc Coordinator critical for multi-block coordination during this period.

L5 Total Hours: Mechanical dominates due to chiller testing, CDU commissioning, CRAH balancing, cooling system integration
Electrical work front-loaded in L4 for power distribution and UPS systems
Load testing and emergency scenarios requiring both disciplines

OEM: Level 4 cannot start until L3 substantially complete. Build 1-week buffer into schedule. Include contractual language about GC readiness
Louisiana weather: Plan outdoor testing early in schedule. Have indoor backup tasks ready. 10% contingency built into schedule
Pre-coordinate vendor startup schedules 4-6 weeks in advance. Have vendor SOWs signed before L4 start
15% retest contingency built in. Maintain punch list tracking. Work with GC to resolve issues during L4 (not after)
Switchyard must be energized before data hall L4 start. Any switchyard delay cascades to all blocks. Monitor closely during Phase 0

Equipment Type: 1. Hours assume equipment has been properly energized and Level 3 (Pre-Functional Testing) completed by GC
2. Mechanical systems represent 62% of total labor due to chiller testing, CDU commissioning, and CRAH balancing complexity
3. Electrical work is more straightforward with shorter per-unit testing times once equipment is energized
4. Level 4 duration: 5 weeks for functional testing with 10-person crew
5. Level 5 duration: 1.5 weeks for integrated systems testing (can be compressed to 1 week if needed)
6. Total target duration: 6.5 weeks provides realistic schedule; 6 weeks achievable with good execution
7. Overhead includes daily coordination meetings, weekly reporting, test documentation, vendor coordination
8. 15% contingency for equipment deficiencies is based on typical data center commissioning punch list rates
9. Battery testing uses statistical sampling per IEEE standards (not full discharge of all 351 cabinets)
10. Pressure testing, flush & fill, and test and balancing (TAB) of liquid/liquid and liquid/air equipment performed by others; PGCIS provides oversight and documentation review only
11. Air and liquid load banks provided and operated by others; PGCIS provides load bank plan review and oversight only
12. Hours do NOT include hands-on pressure testing, flushing, filling, or TAB activities - oversight and witnessing only

Section: COMPLETE STAFFING MODEL - SINGLE 36 MW BLOCK

Discipline: Direct oversight and execution of electrical system commissioning
Direct oversight and execution of mechanical system commissioning
Hands-on electrical testing and data collection
Hands-on mechanical testing and equipment setup
Program oversight across all 6 blocks. Oversees and directs all L4/L5 commissioning activities. Vendor coordination, client interface, issue resolution
Documentation QA/QC, reporting, scheduling support across all 6 blocks. Centralized documentation management
Program-level support not dedicated to single block

Equipment Type: For single 36 MW block commissioning (6.5 weeks), allocate:
Total per-block cost: 3,250 site hours + 300 mgmt hours + 150 doc hours = 3,700 total hours per block
NOTE: Cx Manager and Doc Coordinator costs should be allocated proportionally across all 6 blocks based on active commissioning periods (Aug 2026 - Feb 2027 = 36 weeks total program duration)
STAFFING MODEL: 10-person site team + 1 Cx Manager (hybrid/remote) + 0.5 Doc Coordinator (hybrid/remote)
- Level 4 functional testing: 3,649 hours (5 weeks with 10-person site crew)
- Level 5 integrated testing: 1,499 hours (1.5 weeks with 10-person site crew)
- Program management allocation: 450 hours (300 Cx Mgr + 150 Doc Coord per block)
- Total per block: 5,598 hours (before overhead & contingency)
SCHEDULE: 6.5-7 weeks per 36 MW block is FEASIBLE with baseline staffing and strong management coordination.
Mechanical systems drive schedule due to chiller testing, CDU commissioning, and CRAH balancing complexity (62% of labor).
Cx Manager critical for coordinating overlapping blocks during Oct-Dec 2026 peak period (Blocks 3, 4, 5 active simultaneously).
